Hi!: I was just wondering, if I were to ssh to a machine in my network from a machine outside my network (i have a static ip adress) would i then "ssh user@my.static.ip.adress"? I mean if I check my ip adress online all the computers have the same one :o (Sorry for being a noob)
You need to set port forwarding on your router.
Or even DMZ, if you prefer.
ActionParsnip: So if I open e.g. port 22 the computers will get their own adress and i will ssh into that?
You need to forward port 22 to, say, 192.168.1.111:22, that way when you ssh into your public IP address you'll infact ssh into the computer the port is forwarded to.
If you configure DMZ to 192.168.1.111 then all requests to your public IP will be forwarded to the computer on 192.168.1.111, if that's the right way for you
Let me get it straight, if i open port 22 and i ssh user1@240.25.21.684:22 i can do another to ssh user2@240.25.21.684:22?
Sure, as long as the sshd setup allows that.
Well, uh, yeah... You need to configure an ssh server (for instance, sshd or whatever) to access your computer via SSH
ahh, okay i've got openssh configured :)
Oh, that. You'd need to forward whatever the VNC porn is then
